CatDescriptText: Phenobia Walker, maid, Oakland, and Henry Hester, Hill District, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, January 28, 1961, pg. 21 with question: "Do you favor legislation or voluntary (appealing to the souls and conscience of men) methods, like arbitration, mediation, persuasion, etc., to obtain civil rights for minorities?" Phenobia Walker's answer reads: "I think laws, because people seem to appreciate and respect them better."  Henry Hester's answer reads: "History proves that persuasion is the best means, because laws, being laws, prove they are not popular, so therefore, it's best to rely on the good nature of people to get things done."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Phenobia Walker wearing hat and coat, standing in front of C.A. Michel sign, Smithfield Street, Downtown, another version; Portrait of Henry Hester wearing dark brimmed hat, moustache, light colored scarf, and light colored coat, standing in front of stone building
